alert.note: Alert for Volusia (Florida) Issued by the National Weather Service

info.headline: Flash Flood Warning issued September 29 at 8:52AM EDT until September 29 at 12:00PM EDT by NWS Melbourne
info.description: ...FLASH FLOOD EMERGENCY FOR DAYTONA BEACH, NEW SMYRNA BEACH, PONCE INLET... The National Weather Service in Melbourne has issued a * Flash Flood Warning for... Northeastern Volusia County in east central Florida... * Until noon EDT. * At 852 AM EDT, emergency management reported heavy rain and water rescues in Daytona Beach, New Smyrna Beach, and Ponce Inlet. Between 10 and 14 inches of rain have fallen. Additional rainfall amounts of 3 to 5 inches are possible in the warned area. Flash flooding is already occurring. This is a FLASH FLOOD EMERGENCY for Daytona Beach, New Smyrna Beach, Ponce Inlet. This is a PARTICULARLY DANGEROUS SITUATION. SEEK HIGHER GROUND NOW! HAZARD...Life threatening flash flooding. Heavy rain producing flash flooding. SOURCE...Emergency management reported. IMPACT...This is a PARTICULARLY DANGEROUS SITUATION. SEEK HIGHER GROUND NOW! Life threatening flash flooding of low water crossings, small creeks and streams, urban areas, highways, streets and underpasses. * Some locations that will experience flash flooding include... Daytona Beach, Port Orange, New Smyrna Beach, South Daytona, Holly Hill, Daytona Beach Shores, Daytona Beach Airport, Daytona International Speedway, Ponce Inlet, Spruce Creek, Samsula-Spruce Creek, Allandale, Harbor Oaks, Wilbur By The Sea, New Smyrna Beach Airport and Glencoe. FLASH FLOOD...OBSERVED FLASH FLOOD DAMAGE THREAT...CATASTROPHIC
info.instruction: Move to higher ground now! This is an extremely dangerous and life-threatening situation. Do not attempt to travel unless you are fleeing an area subject to flooding or under an evacuation order. Turn around, don`t drown when encountering flooded roads. Most flood deaths occur in vehicles. Please report observed flooding to local emergency services or law enforcement and request they pass this information to the National Weather Service when you can do so safely.
